required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of the Erector Spinae Plane Block Versus Intrathecal Morphine on Post-Cesarean Delivery Analgesia
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of the Erector Spinae Plane Block Versus Intrathecal Morphine on Post-Cesarean Delivery Analgesia

lead_sponsor.agency: McGill University Health Centre/Research Institute of the McGill University Health Centre

clinical_study.source: McGill University Health Centre/Research Institute of the McGill University Health Centre

brief_summary.textblock: This study is a Randomized Control Trial comparing the Erector Spinae Plane Block with intrathecal morphine for post cesarean delivery analgesia.

primary_outcome.measure: 24 hour area under the curve pain scores
primary_outcome.description: It will be measured at 3 6 12 18 and 24 hours after the end of the cesarean delivery. This pain will be assessed by asking the patient to go from lying to sitting (or use incentive spirometry) and rated using a linear 10 cm visual analogue scale (VAS). The 24 hour pain VAS area under the curve (AUC) will be calculated using the trapezoid rule.

secondary_outcome.measure: Measurement of quality of recovery after cesarean delivery
secondary_outcome.description: At 24 hours the ObsQoR11, a validated instrument to measure the quality of recovery after cesarean delivery, will be administered to the patient
The incidence of nausea and vomiting will be rated on a 10 cm VAS
The cumulative use of opioids, expressed as morphine equivalents will be recorded at 24 hours.
The incidence of pruritus will be rated on a 10 cm VAS
Patients will be contacted by telephone 3 months after the cesarean to assess the presence of chronic pain. This will be done using a modification of the brief pain inventory

intervention.description: A nerve block that injects local anesthetic in the Erector Spinae Plane
Intrathecal morphine at the time of spinal anesthesia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients undergoing scheduled Cesarean delivery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with an ASA score greater than 3
- Allergies to study medications
- Contraindications to neuraxial analgesia
- Patients with chronic pain
- Patients unable to communicate in the study language

overall_official.affiliation: McGill University Health Centre/Research Institute of the McGill University Health Centre

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: McGill University Health Centre/Research Institute of the McGill University Health Centre
